ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Sudden Sensorineural Hearing Loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Acute onset of hearing decrease 6 weeks ago with significant asymmetry in high frequencies.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Presbycusis
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: History of long-standing bilateral high-frequency hearing loss consistent with age.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Vestibular Schwannoma
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss and sudden onset warrant ruling out retrocochlear pathology.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To determine hearing thresholds and configuration of loss.
To assess speech reception thresholds and word recognition ability.
To evaluate middle ear status and tympanic membrane compliance.
To assess the integrity of the reflex arc and screen for retrocochlear pathology.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The evaluation reveals asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss, significantly worse in the right ear at high frequencies (steep slope at 4-6 kHz), superimposed on a background of presbycusis. This is consistent with the patient's report of sudden hearing loss. Word recognition remains excellent bilaterally. Tympanometry indicates a hypercompliant right tympanic membrane (Type Ad) but reflexes are present at low frequencies, suggesting the loss is sensorineural rather than conductive. The asymmetry and sudden onset are red flags requiring medical referral.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Normal sloping to mild SNHL (250-3000 Hz), steeply sloping to severe/profound (4000-6000 Hz). Left ear: Normal sloping to moderate SNHL. Significant high-frequency asymmetry.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRT: Right 12 dB, Left 3 dB. WRS: 96% bilaterally (Right at 65 dB HL, Left at 60 dB HL).

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Hypercompliant (Type Ad, 3.4 mL). Left ear: Normal (Type A, 0.4 mL).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Right ipsilateral absent at 2k and 4k Hz. Left ipsilateral normal. Contralateral absent at 4k Hz bilaterally. Decay negative.

proposed_items: Referral to otologist for medical evaluation
MRI to rule out acoustic neuroma
counseling_actions: Explain the sudden and asymmetric nature of the hearing loss requiring medical attention
Discuss the potential for steroid treatment to attempt hearing restoration
Counsel on the need for MRI to rule out retrocochlear pathology
Discuss benefits of modern hearing aids for high-frequency loss despite previous negative experience

escalation.rationale_short: Sudden asymmetric SNHL requires immediate medical evaluation and MRI to rule out retrocochlear pathology.

follow_up_plan.objective: Medical management of sudden hearing loss and exclusion of retrocochlear pathology, followed by rehabilitation.

expected_outcome: Hearing status: Oral steroids (5 days) did not restore hearing.
Rehabilitation: Patient purchased bilateral hearing aids and perceived them to be beneficial.
